prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple living together where the guy pays all the bills. His girlfriend works part-time and didn't contribute. He's upset about her attitude when he asked her to pay for takeout. Now he's considering making her pay some bills.

First, I need to assess both sides. The author is frustrated because he's handling all the expenses and feels taken for granted. The girlfriend might feel she can't afford it, given her part-time job. The situation is a single incident of $40 takeout, which he sees as unfair. 

Financial responsibilities in relationships can be tricky. If they live together, splitting bills is common. But in this case, the guy hasn't asked her to contribute before. Now, after one incident, he wants her to start paying. Is that fair? Maybe he should have discussed splitting expenses earlier. But maybe he's right that she should contribute, even a little. 

Her reaction might have been because she wasn't expecting it. If she's used to not contributing, a sudden request could cause stress. The author's frustration is about her attitude, but maybe he should have communicated better. However, expecting someone to start contributing after years without it could be seen as abrupt. 

Legally, he's not in the wrong, but emotionally, maybe. He's using one incident to justify a bigger change. The question is whether the author is wrong. If he's been handling everything and now wants a shift, maybe he's not wrong. But if he didn't discuss it before, maybe he's contributing to the issue. 

Considering all angles, the answer might be B—No. He's making a valid point about shared responsibilities, even if the approach could be better. But maybe A if he's being unfair suddenly. Hmm. I think the key is that he's not the one in the wrong. The incident was a trigger for a necessary conversation. So B.
